data.text: @RodnortAnchovy @AustralianSuper You'd be better of with a Retail Advised policy and pay by annual rollover from your Aust Super account. Better policy features, probably lower premiums, you control the policy not some trustee who doesnt hold your personal interests foremost.

@AustralianSuper @Neutron2261 @AustralianSuper - overcharged me the wrong level of insurance premium for 2 years and refused to refund my $$. WARNING: make sure you are only paying the premiums you should be based on your role at work. @AustralianSuper won't alert you in anyway or help you if it's incorrect.
@AustralianSuper Still haven't heard back from you. Great customer service!

@AustralianSuper So the correspondence in 2014 didnt say infer that you had had a win against the insurance companies? Do u think that members adequately understand the differences in 'unlikely to' & 'never ever' going back to work? 
Do u think this passes the 'pub test' that Shorten espouses?

@AustralianSuper Finally....  
1. So was the change better for members when it comes to claim time? 
2. Is the new definition harder to succeed under? 
3. Isnt it better to be able to claim, even if the premiums are higher? as opposed to lower premiums & harder to claim?

@Neutron2261 3/3 I’m sure you can appreciate this is an intricate subject and one not best communicated over tweets. Therefore, further to my previous offer I can organise a conversation with one of our experts if you need more information.
@Neutron2261 2/3  3. These changes were not communicated as a win for members and information on the changes were included in member statements in 2014.

@Neutron2261 1/3 Hi @Neutron2261 -  thank you for your patience. In response to your questions. 1. Our TPD definition changed November 2014. 2. The changes were made with the long term interests of members in mind. As a member organisation, this is central to our purpose.
@AustralianSuper I haven't heard anything from you @AustralianSuper
@AustralianSuper I have sent you my details. Let's see if you do the right thing this time around...
@RodnortAnchovy Hi Rodnort - I'll looking into this. Could you send me your contact details via the private message link below. Thanks https://t.co/jb3sCncaO8
@AustralianSuper @Neutron2261 Give me back my insurance premiums you over charged me for 2 years!!

@AustralianSuper So does that mean that: 1.u arent going to confirm that u changed the definition of TPD in the last few years? https://t.co/OBXxE7QvmH comment on if the new definition is better or worse for members? & https://t.co/HPUJ9Z1PtM confirmation that u sold it as 'a win for members'?

@Neutron2261 We sincerely believe our insurance offering is in members’ interests and you can see the depth of thought that has gone into it in our insurance strategy published on our website. TPD decline rates have reduced over time and are less than 4% for the year to 30 June 2018.

@albericie @RadioNational @abcnews Mr Hodge looked at the fees on cash that gave negative returns. Perhaps he should also have looked at the actual interest earned and what was declared as interest earned. The funds may have skimmed both the return and then fees on the return. Also,was the cash invested in cash?

@albericie @RadioNational @abcnews Think u might do a report on the TPD changes at @AustralianSuper?? 

Changed at detriment to existing members to, in part, make it easy for NEW members to join the fund & get cover. Don't trustees owe duty to EXISTING members?? Seems that ISFs all chasing scale to beat each other
